THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

JUNE 4, 1902.

No, 17.

'THE BALTIMORE EXPERIMENT" AND ITS SUCCESS.

5

OR the past twenty-five years, the Johns Hopkins University has held
a position that is unique in the educational history of our country,
and during this time has come to stand for the most progressive ideals
in her educational life." This recent appreciation from a leading Southern
college but expresses for the South . what President Eliot and President Harper
so graciously and generously voiced for the North and West at our celebration
on the twenty-second of February. The dominant note in these congratulations
was that the Johns Hopkins had not only discovered the true law of creation
and progress in University work, but had also successfully applied it.
When, in 1876, the doors of a few remantled dwelling-houses were modestly
opened to the students, less than 100 in number, who came to study science and
literature under a few great teachers, some skeptic called the new institution
"The Baltimore Experiment." This doubter and his phrase have long since
lost even apparent justification. With the gift of a university site second to
none in America, with a re-endowment of one million dollars dependent only
upon the final subscription of some thousands, now being actively sought, with
a larger student body and teaching staff than ever in her history, with an ex
ceptionally strong and capable administration, and with a quarter century of
almost constant growth for record, it may he confidently asserted that an era of
still greater expansion and opportunity has opened. And the best days are yet
to come. Said President Remsen in his inaugural address: "I believe that a
new day has at last dawned, and that the onward march will soon be taken
up." Great institutions, like great cities, are not built in a day. They grow.
Growth is their vital essence; cessation of progress is death.
The City of Baltimore, the State of Maryland, and the entire South are in
the beginnings of a period of great material development, and for permanent
and best results the intellectual development of their citizens must keep pace
with it. In this era, the Johns Hopkins will be such a factor as was the University of Berlin in the reconstruction of Prussia. But national and international as the fame of the University has become, it still m Itains a peculiarly
close relation to this locality and its future.
Though all sections have shared alike the benefits of her pioneer work for
higher aims and attainments in American education and scholarship, it is
doubtful if anywhere the impulse given to intellectual and material development has been more deservedly appreciated or more zealously cultivated
than in the South.
44

2

THE NEWS—LETTER.

The natural advantage of proximity, and the rapid economic growth of an
era of peace, which restored her ability to seek again, as formerly, the higher
instruction of her youth within her own bounds, led to a quick appreciation in
this region of the unusual opportunities offered, for the first time in America,
by the Johns Hopkins, and to a constantly increasing stream of young men to
her doors.
The State of Maryland, in twenty-five years. has sent to her 2,000 students,
and together with the rest of the South nearly 60 per cent. of the total enrollment. Thus has been fulfilled Dr. Gilman's promise, in his inaugural address
in 1876: that the university's influence should be "first local, then regional, and
then national," that it should be in truth as the heraldic legion on its shield
now proclaims, "An institution devoted to learning, both literary and scientific,
in the State founded by Lord Baltimore."
These were not meaningless phrases. Independent of its environment as
the university was with its magnificent endowment, he chose from the South,
first the men who were to represent this dual idea of the university system, Gildersleeve and Sylvester, former professors in the University of Virginia, fitly
symbolizing the realization in Maryland of the Jeffersonian ideal of higher in
struction conceived for Virginia. From that day fitness, not sectional, religious,
or political affiliation has remained the criterion of selection. Without sectional discrimination, Newcomb, Elliott, Browne and other Southern men were
called to her faculty, and the present staff of instruction contains no less than
forty men of Southern origin or connections, about the same number of Northern, and a similar representation from the West and foreign countries. This
result, though without design, shows the broad liberality that governs the
administration, and the creative work the university is doing for the South as
well as for the rest of the country.
It was here that the literary genius of Sidney Lanier first found appropriate
recognition in appointment to a lectureship and in the much-needed encouragement from Mr. Gilman. We might mention, too, Woodrow Wilson of Princeton, and William P. Trent of Barnard, as typical of her contribution from the
South to the North.
The university will not be the first to disregard the bonds of local attachment that are strengthening year by year. As a Maryland foundation; a "Baltimore experiment;" with locally invested funds fianciered by Marylanders;
endowed with buildings, lectureships, fellowships and scholarships by local
friends; reclaimed from financial embarrassment, twice by private and twice by
public aid in Maryland, re-created by the gift of a new site which Baltimore
will not allow to remain vacant for lack of endowment, she has striven, and
will strive, never merely to balance the account but to return a hundred-fold
the benefits received. That her return to the state and the city, and to the
South alone has made her one of the best paying investments ever secured, no
one familiar with the facts for a moment doubts.
A few of these contributions will be found suggestive: 1. More than any
other influence, the Johns Hopkins University has checked the exodus of youth
to foreign universities—a custom dating from colonial times at the South—by

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

offering them not only equal facilities, but a training more American and more
suited to our Southern needs. In the past year 360 out of a total of 694 students have been enrolled from the South. 2. The poor but deserving young
men of this region have been aided financially and with honors more largely
even than those of other regions. The benefits of 65 annual scholarships out
of a total of 90 are limited to the South, and her sons compete on equal terms
for the other twenty-five and for twenty fellowships. Over 350 Southern men
have received such or greater honors here. 3. Southern Colleges and schools
have been filled with men trained in the best methods of modern research and
instruction, who are an inspiration to their students and instrumental in organizing associations for the advancement of the educational and material interests
of their respective States. Nearly 200 former students of Johns Hopkins are at
present teaching in the South, distributed in every state and among more than
65 institutions. Two hundred more are engaged in business or professional
work in the South. 4. The development of local industries of the highest importance, such as oyster culture in Maryland and Virginia, has been greatly
stimulated. A marine laboratory is maintained for the study of the life of the
Chesapeake and of Southern waters. A physical analysis of soils has been of
great agricultural value. The geological department has accomplished much
for the farmer, promoter, investor and land-owner in determining soil characteristics, water power facilities, transportation conditions, the location of mineral resources and in publishing and distributing its excellent topographical
map and reports for Maryland. 5. The Medical School, aside from the inestimable benefits of its great hospital and trained men and women,has undertaken
researches with good results upon the fatal diseases prevalent in this and Southern regions, such as fevers. 6. The first serious attempt on a large scale to
insure the preservation of the history and literature of the South as written by
her own people, has been made through the historical department, which has
published more than 20 monographs of original research upon Maryland alone,
and 61 upon Southern history, economics, and politics. It has the best collections and library facilities in this field of any American university, and it supplements these by courses of systematic instruction in Southern history and
economics. 7. The bonds between Baltimore and the South, weakened by the
rise of new commercial towns and ports, have been greatly strengthened through
the University's influence; and her twelve periodical publications bear the name
of Baltimore and Maryland to the whole civilized and educated world. 8.
Important principles of the Johns Hopkins system have been copied in many
of the Southern Universities; the requirements for the doctorate, the expansion
of advanced or graduate study, the system of advisers, which insures a personal
direction for the undergraduate and finally, a reliance upon the vital and essential, youth, vigor, enthusiasm, reality and the present, rather than upon dim
tradition and authority.
JAMPS CURTIS BALLAGH.
(Revised and rewritten by the author from hts article in The Evamidist, March 29, noa—ED.)

HE TWENTY-SIXTH ACADEMIC YEAR of the Johns Hopkins University has
been one of progress in every department. With the accession of President Remsen, a new hand has been at the helm; but it has guided with
wisdom, moderation and foresight. The high position that the University has
maintained in the world of education and research was attested at the celebration of her twenty-fifth birthday, when an unparalleled gathering of scholars
brought congratulations and praise from West and East. The many services to
Maryland and the South rendered by the Hopkins are remarked on in the leading article of this issue. The unconditional gift of the Homewood estate has
caused the dream of a splendid home for the University to become a possibility
of the near future.
The financial cloud that for years has hung over us has not yet received its
silver lining. The Committee of Seventy, which shouldered the task of raising
the last quarter million of the endowment fund, report about $117,000 still unsubscribed. But there are sanguine hopes of an announcement on the Commencement Day, June 10.
Coming to undergraduate life, there is to be seen the results of the same old
"Hopkins spirit" which enables our scanty undergraduate body, with the aid of
a few grads. and medical students, to accomplish wonders.
Athletics, as reviewed on another page, have met with success. At the
present time of writing, a lacrosse game is scheduled for June 11 with the Uni-

THEINEWS—LETTER.

5

versity of Toronto team, intercollegiate champions of Canada and Great Britain. We may fairly consider ourselves champions of the United States; so
that the game will be the fiercest, with the gi andest prize for the winner, that
Baltimore will ever have seen or Hopkins ever played. Let us hope that,in thus
stepping from a local to a world arena, our mighty men will not get weak in the
knees from stage-fright.
The Musical Clubs have had a prosperous season, and are keeping out of
financial troubles. The Public Debate was more successful than ever before,
and this year in addition served as a trial for Hopkins, first intercollegiate de
bate, in which our spell-binders did themselves much credit in their maiden
effort, although they lost to North Carolina. The student publications have
been carried on with the customary enthusiasm; the senior annual, just published, is in every way worthy of the graduating class. The long-looked-for
Student Club has been evolved by the Junior Class. Interclass athletics have
been stimulated by two Junior-Freshman relay races and a tug-of-war, in addition to the usual foot ball game and cane rush. Indeed, there are no lines
along which earnest work has not been done, and encouraging results obtained.

TORONTO VERSUS HOPKINS!
A THROW FOR THE INTERCOLLEGIATE LACROSSE CHAMPIONSHIP OF
THE WORLD.

t

HE greatest lacrosse game ever played by Hopkins will take place on June
11, when the crack Canadian twelve will line up against the Black and
Blue at American League Park.
.
The intercollegiate champions of Canada have recently returned from a
tour through England, where they won every contest. That the team from the
North is an all-star aggregation cannot for a moment be doubted, but Hopkins
has put up a wonderful game throughout the present season, and, although the
chances of defeating such an opponent may seem very small, still, all things
are possible. Every man on our team may be expected to do his duty, and it
is "up to" every student, supporter, and friend of the 'Varsity to give the
greatest possible encouragement.
Undoubtedly, we have the strongest team Hopkins has ever had, and, from
the outlook at the present, the strongest which will represent the University for
some time to come. Recognizing that we have reached the zenith of our power,
the management has very wisely embraced the opportunity to try for the world's
championship. Such a game as the contest promises to be is not likely to be
seen again in Baltimore for many years.
The fact that the contest is an international one, decisive of the world's
championship, makes it likely that President Theodore Roosevelt will accept
an invitation to attend. The crowd should be a record breaker.
The men have been on a training diet for several days, and outdoor practice begins to-day. Every effort will be made to get each player in perfect
shape, and the prospects are that on June lithe 'Varsity will trot on the field
in the pink of condition. Let every man help the management by talking up
the game in every direction, and by coming himself.
Scrubs, don't forget the 'Varsity needs you. If everybody will lend a
hand, victory is possible.

SENIOR CLASS WEEK.

t

HE class of '02 begins the festivities of Senior Week tomorrow. At the
noon hour they will form in line for the usual senior procession. In the
course of a tour around the buildings, speeches are made in all the rooms
and responded to by the professors. In the evening President Stone will entertain his class-mates at his home in Towson.
On Friday morning '02 goes to Homewood. The ceremonies have not been
decided upon as yet, but the class expects to plant the class ivy somewhere upon
the estate. In the evening Dean Griffin holds a reception for the class at the
Hopkins Club.
Saturday the class takes an outing at the former home of the Maryland Yacht
Club. The trip is made by the trolley and then by launch to the grounds,
where the afternoon and evening will be spent. On Sunday, June 8, the baccalaureate sermon will be preached by Rev. Amory Howe Bradford, pastor of
the First Congregational Church of Montclair, N. J. Dr. Bradford is an associate editor of the Outlook. The sermon will be delivered at 11 o'clock at the
Associate Congregational Church, corner of Maryland Avenue and Preston
Street.
On Monday the much-heralded senior prom takes place in McCoy Hall
This is strictly an invitation affair, to which seniors alone can issue invitations.
Tuesday is Commencement Day. The exercises will be held at 4 o'clock at
the Academy of Music. At 8 o'clock the University will hold a reception in
McCoy Hall for all the graduates, doctors of philosophy, the medical graduates
and the members of '02.

THE YEAR IN ATHLETICS.
141) JOHNS HOPKINS" may well be proud of the achievements which
his teams have gained in the different branches of athletics since last
September. With our small number of students and the poor facilities for proper training by which we are handicapped, the intercollegiate football championship of Maryland, the championship in track and field work
against all Maryland, and the intercollegiate lacrosse championship of the
United States can by no means be considered a small accomplishment for one
.scholastic year. It is practically all we could have done.
Our championship relay team did not bring home another banner from the
annual relay races at the University of Pennsylvania, but had not W. E. Hoffman fallen by accident, we should most certainly have had one more pennant
for the trophy room. Notwithstanding this, the boys ran a great race, and
came very near winning out anyhow. The track men more than made up for
this defeat, however, by the great work done in the championship games held at
Electric Park on May 14. Hopkins made a total of 60 points while our'nearest
competitor—the Maryland Athletic Club—gained 36 points.
At the beginning of the foot ball season those men who understood the
situation best were sincerely sorry for Captain Gillespie. The vacant positions

TRACK

found impossible to fill. Nothing daunted, however, "Horace" went to work
in an endeavor to squeeze every bit of material that could be found in the
University, and "Mack" led the crusade in search of recruits at the Medical
School. The scores at the beginning of the season were discouraging, but
gradually better material began to appear, and, in the first of our championship
games,—that with Western Maryland College,—we won in good style by a
score of 12 to 0. Nevertheless, the championship game with St. John's was
contemplated with fear and trembling. The Annapolitan crowd did not hesitate to say that they were represented by the strongest team which they had
developed for years, and Dr Cain,'supervisor of athletics at St. John's, wrote
to "Father Bill" and confidently informed him that a good walloping for Hopkins was inevitable. And from St. John's showing against teams like Swarthmore and Gallaudet, things did look somewhat blue. Our men were not discouraged by the prospect. The appearance of such men as Garwood, Faris,
Youtz, Weil, Houghton and Whipple from the Medical School greatly improved

THE NEWS—LETTER.

13

C.'02 RELAY TEAM.

matters and the showing made against Haverford encouraged us to hope that
even St. John's might be beaten.
The day of the game dawned with black clouds frowning down on the
American League Park from every side, and the continuous downpour throughout the afternoon converted the gridiron into one hugs mud-puddle. In the
first half a battle royal was waged and neither side scored; but in the second,
Hopkins' rooters shouted for joy when they saw our men slowly but surely
working the ball towards St. John's goal. The oval was carried to the oneyard line, and, on the third down, St. John's center seeing that the game was
lost unless some sort of strategy were resorted to, interfered with our center
man. The referee promptly gave us first down, and to the visitors' great discredit, they showed the "yellow back" by refusing to play. The only spoitsmanlike action open to them was to finish the game under protest. The game
was promptly forfeited to Hopkins, and with it came the intercollegiate chain
pionship of Maryland.
During the winter, very little was heard from either the track or the lacrosse
teams, but both squads were quietly doing good work in the cage and on April
5 the seasons opened in a manner very satisfactory to our adherents. The

THE NEWS-LETTER.
lacrosse team defeated the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia by
a
score of 6 to 1, and the first track and field games ever held in the "cage"
gave
us a majority of points.
From that time until May 19, lacrosse held sway, and well it might.
Although Tyler, Bruton, J. Bandel and Hatch were lost, good men turned up
to take their places, and when Hobart was beaten in the second game by
a
score of 12 to 1, the rooters joyously shouted, "Our boys are out for the championship!" And they were. Harvard went down on the Saturday following by a score of 11 to 1, and when Swarthmore was played to a standstill, 8-2,
in the closing game, the "has beens" declared the team of 1902 the strongest
ever turned out by Hopkins.
Captain England capped the climax by clipping 2 1.5 seconds off the State
record, at the News Cup games.
With so much to be done in the foregoing branches of sport, it hardly
seemed possible that sufficient material could be spared for base ball. Notwithstanding, Captain Campbell and his men made a very creditable showing under
so many discouraging circumstances. We hope they may improve next year.

THE NIFTY NICKEL-PITCHERS.

Of all the occupations
Which engross the college man
Of all the college pastimes,
Nickel-pitching leads the van.
It used to be that pennies
Were regarded a big stake,
But it was soon decided
That it took too long to break
A bloomin', bloody Freshman
If he had a good sized pile,
And thus at last it happened
That the nickel came in style.
Beware the game so sinful,
For it really can't be beat,
If any new man tries it
He will surely court defeat.
It takes a skillful player
To manipulate the game
To toss up the collection,
And then pocket all the same.

THE .02 TRACK AND FIELD SQUAD.

COMMENCEMENT NUMBER.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
Vol. VI.

JUNE 4, 1902.

No, 17.

'THE BALTIMORE EXPERIMENT" AND ITS SUCCESS.

5

OR the past twenty-five years, the Johns Hopkins University has held
a position that is unique in the educational history of our country,
and during this time has come to stand for the most progressive ideals
in her educational life." This recent appreciation from a leading Southern
college but expresses for the South . what President Eliot and President Harper
so graciously and generously voiced for the North and West at our celebration
on the twenty-second of February. The dominant note in these congratulations
was that the Johns Hopkins had not only discovered the true law of creation
and progress in University work, but had also successfully applied it.
When, in 1876, the doors of a few remantled dwelling-houses were modestly
opened to the students, less than 100 in number, who came to study science and
literature under a few great teachers, some skeptic called the new institution
"The Baltimore Experiment." This doubter and his phrase have long since
lost even apparent justification. With the gift of a university site second to
none in America, with a re-endowment of one million dollars dependent only
upon the final subscription of some thousands, now being actively sought, with
a larger student body and teaching staff than ever in her history, with an ex
ceptionally strong and capable administration, and with a quarter century of
almost constant growth for record, it may he confidently asserted that an era of
still greater expansion and opportunity has opened. And the best days are yet
to come. Said President Remsen in his inaugural address: "I believe that a
new day has at last dawned, and that the onward march will soon be taken
up." Great institutions, like great cities, are not built in a day. They grow.
Growth is their vital essence; cessation of progress is death.
The City of Baltimore, the State of Maryland, and the entire South are in
the beginnings of a period of great material development, and for permanent
and best results the intellectual development of their citizens must keep pace
with it. In this era, the Johns Hopkins will be such a factor as was the University of Berlin in the reconstruction of Prussia. But national and international as the fame of the University has become, it still m Itains a peculiarly
close relation to this locality and its future.
Though all sections have shared alike the benefits of her pioneer work for
higher aims and attainments in American education and scholarship, it is
doubtful if anywhere the impulse given to intellectual and material development has been more deservedly appreciated or more zealously cultivated
than in the South.
44

2

THE NEWS—LETTER.

The natural advantage of proximity, and the rapid economic growth of an
era of peace, which restored her ability to seek again, as formerly, the higher
instruction of her youth within her own bounds, led to a quick appreciation in
this region of the unusual opportunities offered, for the first time in America,
by the Johns Hopkins, and to a constantly increasing stream of young men to
her doors.
The State of Maryland, in twenty-five years. has sent to her 2,000 students,
and together with the rest of the South nearly 60 per cent. of the total enrollment. Thus has been fulfilled Dr. Gilman's promise, in his inaugural address
in 1876: that the university's influence should be "first local, then regional, and
then national," that it should be in truth as the heraldic legion on its shield
now proclaims, "An institution devoted to learning, both literary and scientific,
in the State founded by Lord Baltimore."
These were not meaningless phrases. Independent of its environment as
the university was with its magnificent endowment, he chose from the South,
first the men who were to represent this dual idea of the university system, Gildersleeve and Sylvester, former professors in the University of Virginia, fitly
symbolizing the realization in Maryland of the Jeffersonian ideal of higher in
struction conceived for Virginia. From that day fitness, not sectional, religious,
or political affiliation has remained the criterion of selection. Without sectional discrimination, Newcomb, Elliott, Browne and other Southern men were
called to her faculty, and the present staff of instruction contains no less than
forty men of Southern origin or connections, about the same number of Northern, and a similar representation from the West and foreign countries. This
result, though without design, shows the broad liberality that governs the
administration, and the creative work the university is doing for the South as
well as for the rest of the country.
It was here that the literary genius of Sidney Lanier first found appropriate
recognition in appointment to a lectureship and in the much-needed encouragement from Mr. Gilman. We might mention, too, Woodrow Wilson of Princeton, and William P. Trent of Barnard, as typical of her contribution from the
South to the North.
The university will not be the first to disregard the bonds of local attachment that are strengthening year by year. As a Maryland foundation; a "Baltimore experiment;" with locally invested funds fianciered by Marylanders;
endowed with buildings, lectureships, fellowships and scholarships by local
friends; reclaimed from financial embarrassment, twice by private and twice by
public aid in Maryland, re-created by the gift of a new site which Baltimore
will not allow to remain vacant for lack of endowment, she has striven, and
will strive, never merely to balance the account but to return a hundred-fold
the benefits received. That her return to the state and the city, and to the
South alone has made her one of the best paying investments ever secured, no
one familiar with the facts for a moment doubts.
A few of these contributions will be found suggestive: 1. More than any
other influence, the Johns Hopkins University has checked the exodus of youth
to foreign universities—a custom dating from colonial times at the South—by

THE NEWS—LETTER.

3

offering them not only equal facilities, but a training more American and more
suited to our Southern needs. In the past year 360 out of a total of 694 students have been enrolled from the South. 2. The poor but deserving young
men of this region have been aided financially and with honors more largely
even than those of other regions. The benefits of 65 annual scholarships out
of a total of 90 are limited to the South, and her sons compete on equal terms
for the other twenty-five and for twenty fellowships. Over 350 Southern men
have received such or greater honors here. 3. Southern Colleges and schools
have been filled with men trained in the best methods of modern research and
instruction, who are an inspiration to their students and instrumental in organizing associations for the advancement of the educational and material interests
of their respective States. Nearly 200 former students of Johns Hopkins are at
present teaching in the South, distributed in every state and among more than
65 institutions. Two hundred more are engaged in business or professional
work in the South. 4. The development of local industries of the highest importance, such as oyster culture in Maryland and Virginia, has been greatly
stimulated. A marine laboratory is maintained for the study of the life of the
Chesapeake and of Southern waters. A physical analysis of soils has been of
great agricultural value. The geological department has accomplished much
for the farmer, promoter, investor and land-owner in determining soil characteristics, water power facilities, transportation conditions, the location of mineral resources and in publishing and distributing its excellent topographical
map and reports for Maryland. 5. The Medical School, aside from the inestimable benefits of its great hospital and trained men and women,has undertaken
researches with good results upon the fatal diseases prevalent in this and Southern regions, such as fevers. 6. The first serious attempt on a large scale to
insure the preservation of the history and literature of the South as written by
her own people, has been made through the historical department, which has
published more than 20 monographs of original research upon Maryland alone,
and 61 upon Southern history, economics, and politics. It has the best collections and library facilities in this field of any American university, and it supplements these by courses of systematic instruction in Southern history and
economics. 7. The bonds between Baltimore and the South, weakened by the
rise of new commercial towns and ports, have been greatly strengthened through
the University's influence; and her twelve periodical publications bear the name
of Baltimore and Maryland to the whole civilized and educated world. 8.
Important principles of the Johns Hopkins system have been copied in many
of the Southern Universities; the requirements for the doctorate, the expansion
of advanced or graduate study, the system of advisers, which insures a personal
direction for the undergraduate and finally, a reliance upon the vital and essential, youth, vigor, enthusiasm, reality and the present, rather than upon dim
tradition and authority.
JAMPS CURTIS BALLAGH.

HE TWENTY-SIXTH ACADEMIC YEAR of the Johns Hopkins University has
been one of progress in every department. With the accession of President Remsen, a new hand has been at the helm; but it has guided with
wisdom, moderation and foresight. The high position that the University has
maintained in the world of education and research was attested at the celebration of her twenty-fifth birthday, when an unparalleled gathering of scholars
brought congratulations and praise from West and East. The many services to
Maryland and the South rendered by the Hopkins are remarked on in the leading article of this issue. The unconditional gift of the Homewood estate has
caused the dream of a splendid home for the University to become a possibility
of the near future.
The financial cloud that for years has hung over us has not yet received its
silver lining. The Committee of Seventy, which shouldered the task of raising
the last quarter million of the endowment fund, report about $117,000 still unsubscribed. But there are sanguine hopes of an announcement on the Commencement Day, June 10.
Coming to undergraduate life, there is to be seen the results of the same old
"Hopkins spirit" which enables our scanty undergraduate body, with the aid of
a few grads. and medical students, to accomplish wonders.
Athletics, as reviewed on another page, have met with success. At the
present time of writing, a lacrosse game is scheduled for June 11 with the Uni-

THEINEWS—LETTER.

5

versity of Toronto team, intercollegiate champions of Canada and Great Britain. We may fairly consider ourselves champions of the United States; so
that the game will be the fiercest, with the gi andest prize for the winner, that
Baltimore will ever have seen or Hopkins ever played. Let us hope that,in thus
stepping from a local to a world arena, our mighty men will not get weak in the
knees from stage-fright.
The Musical Clubs have had a prosperous season, and are keeping out of
financial troubles. The Public Debate was more successful than ever before,
and this year in addition served as a trial for Hopkins, first intercollegiate de
bate, in which our spell-binders did themselves much credit in their maiden
effort, although they lost to North Carolina. The student publications have
been carried on with the customary enthusiasm; the senior annual, just published, is in every way worthy of the graduating class. The long-looked-for
Student Club has been evolved by the Junior Class. Interclass athletics have
been stimulated by two Junior-Freshman relay races and a tug-of-war, in addition to the usual foot ball game and cane rush. Indeed, there are no lines
along which earnest work has not been done, and encouraging results obtained.

TORONTO VERSUS HOPKINS!
A THROW FOR THE INTERCOLLEGIATE LACROSSE CHAMPIONSHIP OF
THE WORLD.

t

HE greatest lacrosse game ever played by Hopkins will take place on June
11, when the crack Canadian twelve will line up against the Black and
Blue at American League Park.
.
The intercollegiate champions of Canada have recently returned from a
tour through England, where they won every contest. That the team from the
North is an all-star aggregation cannot for a moment be doubted, but Hopkins
has put up a wonderful game throughout the present season, and, although the
chances of defeating such an opponent may seem very small, still, all things
are possible. Every man on our team may be expected to do his duty, and it
is "up to" every student, supporter, and friend of the 'Varsity to give the
greatest possible encouragement.
Undoubtedly, we have the strongest team Hopkins has ever had, and, from
the outlook at the present, the strongest which will represent the University for
some time to come. Recognizing that we have reached the zenith of our power,
the management has very wisely embraced the opportunity to try for the world's
championship. Such a game as the contest promises to be is not likely to be
seen again in Baltimore for many years.
The fact that the contest is an international one, decisive of the world's
championship, makes it likely that President Theodore Roosevelt will accept
an invitation to attend. The crowd should be a record breaker.
The men have been on a training diet for several days, and outdoor practice begins to-day. Every effort will be made to get each player in perfect
shape, and the prospects are that on June lithe 'Varsity will trot on the field
in the pink of condition. Let every man help the management by talking up
the game in every direction, and by coming himself.
Scrubs, don't forget the 'Varsity needs you. If everybody will lend a
hand, victory is possible.

SENIOR CLASS WEEK.

t

HE class of '02 begins the festivities of Senior Week tomorrow. At the
noon hour they will form in line for the usual senior procession. In the
course of a tour around the buildings, speeches are made in all the rooms
and responded to by the professors. In the evening President Stone will entertain his class-mates at his home in Towson.
On Friday morning '02 goes to Homewood. The ceremonies have not been
decided upon as yet, but the class expects to plant the class ivy somewhere upon
the estate. In the evening Dean Griffin holds a reception for the class at the
Hopkins Club.
Saturday the class takes an outing at the former home of the Maryland Yacht
Club. The trip is made by the trolley and then by launch to the grounds,
where the afternoon and evening will be spent. On Sunday, June 8, the baccalaureate sermon will be preached by Rev. Amory Howe Bradford, pastor of
the First Congregational Church of Montclair, N. J. Dr. Bradford is an associate editor of the Outlook. The sermon will be delivered at 11 o'clock at the
Associate Congregational Church, corner of Maryland Avenue and Preston
Street.
On Monday the much-heralded senior prom takes place in McCoy Hall
This is strictly an invitation affair, to which seniors alone can issue invitations.
Tuesday is Commencement Day. The exercises will be held at 4 o'clock at
the Academy of Music. At 8 o'clock the University will hold a reception in
McCoy Hall for all the graduates, doctors of philosophy, the medical graduates
and the members of '02.

THE YEAR IN ATHLETICS.
141) JOHNS HOPKINS" may well be proud of the achievements which
his teams have gained in the different branches of athletics since last
September. With our small number of students and the poor facilities for proper training by which we are handicapped, the intercollegiate football championship of Maryland, the championship in track and field work
against all Maryland, and the intercollegiate lacrosse championship of the
United States can by no means be considered a small accomplishment for one
.scholastic year. It is practically all we could have done.
Our championship relay team did not bring home another banner from the
annual relay races at the University of Pennsylvania, but had not W. E. Hoffman fallen by accident, we should most certainly have had one more pennant
for the trophy room. Notwithstanding this, the boys ran a great race, and
came very near winning out anyhow. The track men more than made up for
this defeat, however, by the great work done in the championship games held at
Electric Park on May 14. Hopkins made a total of 60 points while our'nearest
competitor—the Maryland Athletic Club—gained 36 points.

situation best were sincerely sorry for Captain Gillespie. The vacant positions

TRACK

found impossible to fill. Nothing daunted, however, "Horace" went to work
in an endeavor to squeeze every bit of material that could be found in the
University, and "Mack" led the crusade in search of recruits at the Medical
School. The scores at the beginning of the season were discouraging, but
gradually better material began to appear, and, in the first of our championship
games,—that with Western Maryland College,—we won in good style by a
score of 12 to 0. Nevertheless, the championship game with St. John's was
contemplated with fear and trembling. The Annapolitan crowd did not hesitate to say that they were represented by the strongest team which they had
developed for years, and Dr Cain,'supervisor of athletics at St. John's, wrote
to "Father Bill" and confidently informed him that a good walloping for Hopkins was inevitable. And from St. John's showing against teams like Swarthmore and Gallaudet, things did look somewhat blue. Our men were not discouraged by the prospect. The appearance of such men as Garwood, Faris,
Youtz, Weil, Houghton and Whipple from the Medical School greatly improved

THE NEWS—LETTER.

13

C.'02 RELAY TEAM.

matters and the showing made against Haverford encouraged us to hope that
even St. John's might be beaten.
The day of the game dawned with black clouds frowning down on the
American League Park from every side, and the continuous downpour throughout the afternoon converted the gridiron into one hugs mud-puddle. In the
first half a battle royal was waged and neither side scored; but in the second,
Hopkins' rooters shouted for joy when they saw our men slowly but surely
working the ball towards St. John's goal. The oval was carried to the oneyard line, and, on the third down, St. John's center seeing that the game was
lost unless some sort of strategy were resorted to, interfered with our center
man. The referee promptly gave us first down, and to the visitors' great discredit, they showed the "yellow back" by refusing to play. The only spoitsmanlike action open to them was to finish the game under protest. The game
was promptly forfeited to Hopkins, and with it came the intercollegiate chain
pionship of Maryland.
During the winter, very little was heard from either the track or the lacrosse
teams, but both squads were quietly doing good work in the cage and on April
5 the seasons opened in a manner very satisfactory to our adherents. The

THE NEWS-LETTER.
lacrosse team defeated the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia by
a
score of 6 to 1, and the first track and field games ever held in the "cage"
gave
us a majority of points.
From that time until May 19, lacrosse held sway, and well it might.
Although Tyler, Bruton, J. Bandel and Hatch were lost, good men turned up
to take their places, and when Hobart was beaten in the second game by
a
score of 12 to 1, the rooters joyously shouted, "Our boys are out for the championship!" And they were. Harvard went down on the Saturday following by a score of 11 to 1, and when Swarthmore was played to a standstill, 8-2,
in the closing game, the "has beens" declared the team of 1902 the strongest
ever turned out by Hopkins.
Captain England capped the climax by clipping 2 1.5 seconds off the State
record, at the News Cup games.
With so much to be done in the foregoing branches of sport, it hardly
seemed possible that sufficient material could be spared for base ball. Notwithstanding, Captain Campbell and his men made a very creditable showing under
so many discouraging circumstances. We hope they may improve next year.

THE NIFTY NICKEL-PITCHERS.

Of all the occupations
Which engross the college man
Of all the college pastimes,
Nickel-pitching leads the van.
It used to be that pennies
Were regarded a big stake,
But it was soon decided
That it took too long to break
A bloomin', bloody Freshman
If he had a good sized pile,
And thus at last it happened
That the nickel came in style.
Beware the game so sinful,
For it really can't be beat,
If any new man tries it
He will surely court defeat.
It takes a skillful player
To manipulate the game
To toss up the collection,
And then pocket all the same.
L'ENVOI.

You have got my little all,
And ne'er again I'll linger
Pitching nickels at the wall.
